questions.question_text:
Examine this configuration:
1. CDB1 is an Oracle Database 12c Release 2 database containing pluggable databases PDB$SEED, PDB1, and PDB2.
2. PDB$SEED is open READ ONLY
3. PDB1 is open READ WRITE
4. PDB2 is MOUNTED.
5. ORACLE_HOME is /u01/app/oracle/product/18.1.0/dbhome_1.
You execute these commands before upgrading the database to the current release:
//IMG//

For which databases will fixup scripts be created?

comments.content:
Agree with you.

Also tested in my database:

[oracle@apex tmp]$ $ORA-CLE_HOME/jdk/bin/java -jar preupgrade.jar TERMINAL TEXT
INFORMATION - Container: XEPDB2 is in: MOUNTED status and will not be processed unless opened.

discussion.content:
e correct!

For multitenant architecture (CDB and PDB) upgrades, open up all the PDBs that you want the tool to analyze before you run the tool.

comments.content:
E correct.

The script will not perform a change, but will fetch information.

discussion.content:
I think all of them are wrong as PDB$SEED is not open for generate access or modification, preupgrade.jar cannot directly generate fixup script for it.

But from the answers above, E is the most correct answer although it includes PDB$SEED. A, B & D must be wrong as PDB2 is wrong.

Selected Answer: E
i think e

Selected Answer: E
E is correct
i think E is correct, right?

choices.C: FLASHBACK TABLE can undrop a column.
choices.D: FLASHBACK DROP can undrop an index when undropping a table.
choices.B: FLASHBACK VERSION QUERY can retrieve REDO records from ONLINE and ARCHIVED REDO LOG files.
choices.E: After a database is restored from flashback logs using the FLASHBACK DATABASE command, it is sometimes rolled forward using redo logs.
choices.A: FLASHBACK QUERY can retrieve REDO records from ONLINE and ARCHIVED REDO LOG files.

questions.question_text: Which two are true about Oracle Flashback features? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
not a-b because flashback use undo not redo/archive.
not c because flashback table cannot rever ddl
d-e -> as of before drop retrieve from the recycle bin also the related index, and after using flashback database command, sometimes you could go forward with redo.
This response is wrong, flashback query use UNDO, not archivelogs, i think right answer must be D and E

Selected Answer: DE
i think de

Selected Answer: DE
D + E is correct
Agree with D & E for the same reason. all other uses UNDO.

questions.question_text: Which three are true about an application seed pluggable database (PDB)? (Choose three.)

choices.A: It is automatically synchronized with its application root PDB when an application is upgraded.
choices.F: A new application PDB created by cloning an application seed PDB can have an up-to-date version of the application installed after cloning completes.
choices.C: A new application PDB created by cloning an application seed PDB can have an old version of the application installed after cloning completes.
choices.G: It is not required in an application container.
choices.D: It is automatically synchronized with its application root PDB when an application is installed.
choices.E: It cannot be dropped from its application container.
choices.B: It cannot be added to an application container after the application container has already been created.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CFG
- An application seed is an optional, user-created PDB within an application container. You can use the DROP PLUGGABLE DATABASE statement to drop an application seed. You can drop an application seed when you no longer need it.

- After the application seed is created, it is synchronized with the application root so that the applications are installed in the application seed.

- When an application in the application root is upgraded or patched, the application seed must be synchronized with the application root to apply these changes.

Selected Answer: CFG
CFG is correct

To create an application container, the current container must be the CDB root and you must specify the AS APPLICATION CONTAINER clause in the CREATE PLUGGABLE DATABASE statement. You must create the application container using Oracle Managed Files. so F is wrong 

Note: An application container cannot be unplugged or dropped if any application PDBs belong to it. so E is correct

choices.A: Uncommitted transactions in PDB1 have been rolled back.
choices.C: Uncommitted transactions in CDB1 and PDB1 have been rolled back.

questions.question_text:
Examine this configuration:
1. CDB1 is a container database.
2. PDB1 and PDB2 are pluggable databases in CDB1.
3. PDB1 and PDB2 are OPEN in READ WRITE mode.
You execute these commands successfully:
//IMG//

Which two are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I had test this on my lab. the Answer should be AB

PDB1 will be in mounted mode actually:

SQL> show con_name;

CON_NAME
------------------------------
PDB1
SQL> shutdown immediate;
Pluggable Database closed.
SQL> alter session set container=cdb$root;

Session altered.

SQL> show pdbs;

 CON_ID CON_NAME OPEN MODE RESTRICTED
---------- ------------------------------ ---------- ----------
 2 PDB$SEED READ ONLY NO
 3 PDB1 MOUNTED

With 19c it does not let you shutdown immediate and says : SQL> shutdown immediate 
ORA-01097: cannot shutdown while in a transaction - commit or rollback first

Selected Answer: AB
i think ab

Selected Answer: AB
https://www.oracletutorial.com/oracle-administration/oracle-shutdown/
During the SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATE, all the connected sessions are disconnected immediately, all uncommitted transactions are rolled back, and the database completely shuts down.

questions.question_text: Which three are true about Automatic Workload Repository (AWR), Automatic Database Diagnostic Monitor (ADDM), and the Manageability Monitor (MMON) background process? (Choose three.)

choices.C: By default, MMON creates an AWR snapshot every 30 minutes.
choices.D: ADDM performs its analysis only when a DBA requests it.
choices.B: ADDM can recommend extending the buffer cache.
choices.A: ADDM can recommend shrinking the buffer cache.
choices.E: By default, AWR snapshots are automatically purged after eight days.
choices.F: AWR snapshots must be deleted when no longer required by ADDM.

comments.content:
AWR Snapshot's default interval is 1 hour and retention is 8 days. It means All AWR statistics are collected every 1 hour and they are kept 8 days by default. 

That means E is correct and F is wrong… so final correct answers are A; B; E

discussion.content:
ABE
F incorrect because AWR snapshots are deleted automatically.

Selected Answer: ABE
A,B,E i think

AWR (Automatic Workload Repository) snapshots cannot be created directly in the CDB$ROOT container in Oracle Database. AWR is a feature of Oracle Database that collects and stores performance statistics for diagnosing performance issues. 

B is a wrong answer

Selected Answer: ABE
i think abe

ABE.
F =false. AWR snapshots must be deleted when no longer required by ADDM. => This is automatically

Selected Answer: ABE
ABE 
Ref.: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/tgdba/automatic-performance-diagnostics.html#GUID-0C89C9A5-A9EE-4E65-95F8-208C9EA36743
Ref.: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/tgdba/gathering-database-statistics.html#GUID-144711F9-85AE-4281-B548-3E01280F9A56

Is F the correct answer?
Or is X correct?
B...〇、C...×、D...×、E...〇
